questiontext.text: A ticket is marked as resolved, but the customer contacts support again within 24 hours. Which KPI most directly captures this failure mode?

answer.text: Mean Resolution Time (mean(Resolution_Minutes))

feedback.text: Incorrect. Resolution time can be short and still produce re-contact if closure is not trusted.

answer.text: First Contact Resolution Rate (mean(First_Contact_Resolution_Flag))

feedback.text: Incorrect. FCR is about whether the issue was solved on the first attempt, not whether the customer returned after closure.

answer.text: Complaint Recurrence Probability (mean(Repeat_Contact_Flag))

feedback.text: Correct. Repeat_Contact_Flag directly measures the probability of customers re-contacting after closure.

answer.text: Average Response Time (mean(Response_Minutes))

feedback.text: Incorrect. Response time measures initial acknowledgment speed, not re-contact after closure.

questiontext.text: Average Response Time improves significantly, but First Contact Resolution Rate does not change. What is the most accurate interpretation?

answer.text: Customers are acknowledged faster, but first-time closure correctness has not improved.

feedback.text: Correct. Response_Minutes improved, but First_Contact_Resolution_Flag did not, so speed improved without improving correctness.

answer.text: Mean Resolution Time must decrease automatically because response is faster.

feedback.text: Incorrect. A faster first response does not guarantee faster closure; handling and handoffs may still dominate resolution time.

answer.text: Customer Effort Score must decrease automatically because response is faster.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Effort is driven by follow-ups, handoffs, and repeated explanations; speed alone may not reduce effort.

answer.text: Repeat Contact Probability must fall automatically because customers received a first response quickly.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Customers can still re-contact if closure is incomplete or not trusted, even with fast initial acknowledgment.

name.text: Q3. Same Resolution Time, Different Effort

questiontext.text: Two channels have similar Mean Resolution Time, but Channel A has a much higher Customer Effort Score. What is the most plausible cause?

answer.text: Channel A is closing tickets too quickly, so effort rises by definition.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Faster closure does not mechanically increase effort; effort reflects customer friction and repeated actions.

answer.text: Channel A likely causes more follow-ups, handoffs, or repeated explanations during handling.

feedback.text: Correct. Customer_Effort_Score captures friction such as repeated contacts and handoffs, even if total closure time is similar.

answer.text: Channel A must have higher sentiment scores, which directly increases effort.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Sentiment and effort may correlate, but sentiment does not directly define effort; process friction drives effort.

answer.text: Customer Effort Score is redundant if Mean Resolution Time is the same.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Time and effort measure different breakdowns; equal time does not imply equal friction.

questiontext.text: Predictive analytics here uses system logic, not ML. If ticket arrivals increase by 15 percent while response and escalation rules remain unchanged, what is the most likely outcome?

answer.text: KPIs remain stable because policies did not change.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Higher arrivals increase congestion and delays even if policies are unchanged.

answer.text: Response and/or resolution delays increase, which increases effort and repeat contacts.

feedback.text: Correct. With higher arrivals and unchanged rules, delays compound, and customers typically follow up more often.

answer.text: First Contact Resolution Rate increases because agents see more tickets.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Higher volume does not improve correctness; it usually increases rework and reduces effective quality.

answer.text: Customer Effort Score decreases because customers become more tolerant over time.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Higher delays usually increase follow-ups and friction, not tolerance.

questiontext.text: You propose a policy trigger: escalate if Priority is High/Critical AND sentiment is negative AND Response_Minutes is above the 75th percentile. Why use a percentile threshold instead of a fixed number of minutes?

answer.text: It adapts to the current performance distribution and consistently targets the slow tail.

feedback.text: Correct. Percentiles track relative performance and flag the worst delays even as overall speed changes.

answer.text: It guarantees that exactly 75 percent of tickets will be escalated.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Above the 75th percentile means roughly the slowest 25 percent meet the speed condition, but other conditions also apply.

answer.text: It removes the need to compute Response_Minutes and simplifies the dataset.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Percentiles still require Response_Minutes; they are computed from its distribution.

answer.text: It ensures escalation is based only on sentiment, not speed.

feedback.text: Incorrect. The trigger explicitly includes speed (Response_Minutes) in addition to sentiment and priority.
